string-array.name: milestones
string-array.item: Just a walk in the park
You\'re SnakeGo accomplishments will be recorded in the annals of history

resources.string:
Snake Poetry for our fellow SnakeGoers…

The appearance of a snake can evoke intense feelings of terror. And rightly so considering a snakebite can be so deadly. But beyond this visceral response, the snake is a multifaceted symbol. A little investigating reveals rich histories of the snake showing up in literature, art, and mythologies from around the world. Some of the following descriptions are among the most prevalent meanings attributed to the snake, despite cultural inflections: 

renewal, as snakes periodically shed their skin, spiritual and physical rebirth, resurrection, life, Mother Earth, pregnancy, primordial nature, the sea, good and evil, the sun and moon, power, knowledge, cunning, deceit, and death. Snakes are sometimes portrayed as guardians of treasure, esoteric knowledge, and the afterlife. They also connote venom, medicine, expanded consciousness, the elixir of life, and immortality.

In Greek mythology, Asclepius is a god of healing and medicine who carries a snake entwined staff. The rod of Asclepius as its often called can be found throughout the world on flags and emblems of distinguished medical institutions, such as the World Health Organization and the American Medical Association. Although their meanings overlap, this rod is sometimes confused with the Caduceus, a rod with wings and two snakes wrapped around it, carried by the Greek god Hermes. Two snakes coiled around each other, a tree, or a staff in this case, tends to signify the union of opposing forces, similar to the yin and the yang. 

Similarly, the Ouroboros is a well-known example of snake iconography which depicts a snake eating its tail. This represents cyclic manifestation, re-absorption, wholeness, infinity, self-creative divinities, and the generative Earth.

The snake is broadly considered to be synonymous with the serpent. In some East Asian cultures, there's no distinction between snakes, serpents, and dragons. 

With so many meanings attached to the snake, it's a difficult creature to pin down, figuratively. How does the snake fit into our lives? Why do we impart such significance to the snake, and why such cultural recurrence - in art, movies, and literature? 

One element of the snake's appeal is arguably its difficulty in being pinned down. This snake mysticism comes at least in part from its skin shedding trait. The snake's impression of continual rejuvenation combined with the terror, awe, and mystery of a snakebite's lethal venom parallels life in many ways. And life is defined by its opposite, death. The paradox of life eating life, creating death (from the Ouroboros) … changing, evolving, self-generating… This is a conundrum for humanity that percolates out (and in) - beyond to infinity, residing in a timeless place, constituting an unnameable transcendence. As such, the snake stays. 

SnakeGo



















 
















Sources 

Wikipedia 

An Illustrated Encyclopedia of Traditional Symbols by J.C. Cooper 

The Power of Myth by Joseph Campbell 

Dictionary.com
